title: 103_s1524
content: The curr_chunk states the repeal of retroactive application of income, estate, and gift tax rate increases. The curr_chunk discusses amendments to income tax rates for taxable years beginning in 1993, including changes to tax percentages and dollar amounts in rate brackets. Amendments to income tax rates for taxable years beginning in 1993 include changes to tax percentages and dollar amounts in rate brackets. The Code of 1986 is amended to insert specific percentages for the year 1993, and special rules apply for that year. Additionally, a section of the Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1993 is amended by striking a subsection. The Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1993 is amended by striking subsection (d) and changing the effective date for estate and gift tax rates from December 31, 1992, to August 10, 1993. SEC. 2. REDUCTION IN ADMINISTRATIVE EXPENSES. Budget Obligations: Departments and agencies must reduce expenses by $3 billion in outlays for fiscal years 1994-1996. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will set obligation limits to achieve this. Discretionary spending limits for fiscal years 1994-1998 will also be reduced by $3 billion in 1994, $6 billion in 1995, and $9 billion in 1996-1998. The Act does not negate the general authority of department heads to make determinations on which services and goods to obligate for in the best interest of performing their duties. The Act allows department heads to determine expenses for services and goods in the best interest of their duties, unless specific provisions state otherwise. Expenses are defined as object classes identified by the Office of Management and Budget. The Act allows department heads to determine expenses for services and goods in the best interest of their duties, unless specific provisions state otherwise. Expenses are defined as object classes identified by the Office of Management and Budget. Consulting services, other services, and supplies and materials are included in the expenses, excluding those of the Department of Defense.
